column1: Father Wolf waited till his cubs could run a little
column2: and then on the night of the Pack Meeting took them and Mowgli and Mother Wolf to the Council Rock—a hilltop covered with stones and boulders where a hundred wolves could hide. Akela
column4: who led all the Pack by strength and cunning
column5: lay out at full length on his rock
column6: and below him sat forty or more wolves of every size and color
column7: from badger-colored veterans who could handle a buck alone to young black three-year-olds who thought they could. The Lone Wolf had led them for a year now. He had fallen twice into a wolf trap in his youth
column8: and once he had been beaten and left for dead; so he knew the manners and customs of men. There was very little talking at the Rock. The cubs tumbled over each other in the center of the circle where their mothers and fathers sat
column9: and now and again a senior wolf would go quietly up to a cub
column11: and return to his place on noiseless feet.
